title: Problem Overview
content: This module formalizes **Erdos Problem #906**: Is there a transcendental entire function whose derivative zeros are dense for ANY subsequence? Erdos claimed solved but no proof exists.
mathContext: An entire function is holomorphic everywhere on C. Transcendental means not a polynomial. The question requires a very strong density property for zeros of arbitrary derivative subsequences.

title: Imports and Setup
content: We import **Complex analysis**, **Calculus** for derivatives, **Topology** for density, and **Polynomial** for the trivial case.
mathContext: Mathlib provides Differentiable for entire functions, Dense for topology, and Polynomial for the counterexample showing why transcendental is required.

title: Entire Functions
content: **IsEntire f** means f is differentiable at every point of C. This is equivalent to being holomorphic everywhere, hence 'entire'.
mathContext: Examples: polynomials, exp, sin, cos. Non-examples: 1/z (pole at 0), log (branch cut). Entire functions are incredibly well-behaved globally.

title: Transcendental Functions
content: **IsTranscendental f** means f is not equal to any polynomial. This excludes functions like z^2 + 1 but includes exp, sin, cos.
mathContext: Transcendental entire functions have infinitely many nonzero derivatives (unlike polynomials). The problem requires this because polynomials trivially satisfy the property.

title: Iterated Derivatives
content: **iteratedDeriv n f** gives the n-th derivative f^{(n)}. We axiomatize the 0th derivative is f, and (n+1)th is derivative of nth.
mathContext: For exp, all derivatives equal exp. For polynomials of degree d, the (d+1)th derivative is zero. This captures f', f'', f''', etc.

title: Derivative Zero Set
content: **derivativeZeroSet f n** = {z : exists k, f^{(n(k))}(z) = 0}. This collects all zeros of derivatives at positions given by sequence n.
mathContext: If n = (1, 3, 5, ...), we collect zeros of f', f''', f^{(5)}, etc. The union of all these zero sets for the given subsequence.

title: The Dense Zeros Property
content: **HasDenseDerivativeZeros f** means for ALL strictly increasing sequences n, the derivativeZeroSet f n is dense in C.
mathContext: This is remarkably strong: no matter how sparse a subsequence of derivatives you pick, their zeros must be dense. This rules out most known functions.

title: Polynomials Are Trivial
content: **polynomial_trivial** shows any polynomial satisfies HasDenseDerivativeZeros. This is why transcendental is required in the problem.
mathContext: A degree-d polynomial has f^{(n)} = 0 for all n > d. So any subsequence eventually hits zeros everywhere, making the zero set all of C (trivially dense).

title: The Open Question
content: **erdos_906_open** axiomatizes the unknown: does such a transcendental entire function exist? Erdos claimed YES but no proof is known.
mathContext: Erdos wrote in 1982 it was 'solved more than ten years ago' but gave no reference. The formal-conjectures project marks this OPEN due to no verified proof.

title: Formal Statement
content: **erdos_906_statement** packages the full question: exists f that is entire, nonzero, transcendental, AND has dense derivative zeros.
mathContext: All four conditions are necessary: nonzero prevents f = 0; transcendental excludes polynomials; entire ensures all derivatives exist; dense zeros is the property.

title: Exponential is Entire and Transcendental
content: **exp_is_entire** and **exp_is_transcendental** show e^z satisfies two of the required properties.
mathContext: exp is the quintessential transcendental entire function. Its derivatives all equal itself, so it's infinitely differentiable and not a polynomial.

title: Exponential Fails the Property
content: **exp_deriv_never_zero** and **exp_no_zeros** show that exp does NOT have the dense zeros property - in fact it has NO zeros at all!
mathContext: Since all derivatives of e^z equal e^z, and e^z != 0 for all z in C, the derivativeZeroSet is empty for any subsequence. This is the opposite of dense.

title: Related Concepts
content: Connections to **Polya** (zeros of polynomial derivatives) and **Weierstrass factorization** (constructing functions with prescribed zeros).
mathContext: Polya's shire theorem says polynomial derivative zeros stay in the convex hull of the original zeros. Weierstrass lets you build entire functions with any zero set.

title: Zero Set Properties
content: **zero_set_closed** shows derivative zero sets are closed. **individual_zero_sets_discrete** notes individual derivative zeros are isolated for non-constant entire functions.
mathContext: Each f^{(k)} has isolated zeros (unless identically zero), but the UNION over a subsequence can be dense. This is the subtlety the problem exploits.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_906_summary** packages: polynomials satisfy the property, and exp is entire and transcendental (but doesn't satisfy the property).
mathContext: This demonstrates the gap: polynomials work trivially, exp fails completely. The question is whether some other transcendental entire function works.
